content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose B{}. This strategy is based on the expectation that my opponent, being moderately cautious like me, might lean towards avoiding risk and choosing a more secure option. Choosing B gives me a slightly higher average payoff (40$ per round) compared to R (35$) if my opponent chooses the same as me in each round. Over 75 rounds, this small difference adds up significantly. However, I am aware that there is a risk of losing all earnings in some rounds if my opponent chooses R, but I believe the overall higher potential payoff from choosing B outweighs this risk. This is a rational decision based on maximizing expected value and minimizing risk, given the information provided about the anonymous player's characteristics.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

I would choose B again{}. My strategy remains unchanged, as my initial assumption about the opponent's preferences was correct. Choosing B continues to offer me a slightly higher average payoff per round compared to R, even though there is still a risk of losing all earnings in some rounds if my opponent chooses R. Over many rounds, this small difference adds up significantly. In this case, since both of us chose B in the previous round, we will again receive 40$ each.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I would choose R{}. In this situation, my previous strategy of choosing B did not work out because my opponent chose R instead. Now, since my opponent has already chosen R in the current round, it is unlikely that they will change their strategy and choose B in the future rounds, as choosing R gives them a higher payoff when I choose B (35$ compared to 0$). Therefore, I should try to capitalize on this knowledge and switch my strategy to choosing R. This way, if my opponent sticks with their current strategy of choosing R, I will receive 35$ per round instead of 0$. However, there is still a small chance that they might change their strategy and choose B in future rounds, which would result in me receiving 40$ per round. Overall, choosing R offers a higher potential payoff (35$) compared to the previous choice of B (20$), even though it also comes with a higher risk of receiving 0$ if my opponent sticks with their current strategy of choosing R. This is a rational decision based on minimizing risk and maximizing potential payoff, given the information provided about the opponent's previous choice.
